item.title: Tech Giant Aims to Cut Ties With Russia
item.description: The departure of the parent of the company known as “Russia’s Google” would be a setback to President Vladimir V. Putin’s efforts to develop homegrown substitutes for Western technology.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A residential building that was hit by a Russian missile on Wednesday in Vyshhorod, Ukraine.

item.title: Under Missile Strikes, Ukrainians Haul Water, While Surgeons Work in the Dark
item.description: “Every hour is getting harder.” Russia’s assault on Ukraine’s essential services has caused blackouts in hospitals and cut off power and water in cities.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The darkened streets of Kyiv on Wednesday night after a wave of Russian missile strikes that targeted energy facilities across the country.

item.title: iPhone Factory Protest Challenges China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Rules
item.description: Protests are rising as China enacts more lockdowns and quarantines, with no end in sight. The defiance is a test of Xi Jinping’s authoritarian leadership.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Chang Che, John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: via AFP— Getty; via Reuters, via AFP— Getty
item.media:description: Social media videos posted on Wednesday showing workers protesting at Foxconn’s iPhone factory in Zhengzhou in central China.

item.title: Manx Language Is Experiencing a Revival on the Isle of Man
item.description: After being nearly silenced, Manx is experiencing a revival on the Isle of Man, thanks in part to an elementary school and some impassioned parents.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Bunscoill Ghaelgagh, a school on the Isle of Man, evidence that Manx was still very much in use was practically everywhere.

item.title: A US-Made Missile Went Astray in Ukraine, Injuring Civilians
item.description: An air-launched AGM-88B missile, built to destroy enemy radars, apparently missed its target and hit an apartment building in Kramatorsk in September.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: AGM-88 air-to-surface missiles aboard the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford off the coast of Virginia in October.

item.title: Lawmakers Back Bill to Enshrine Abortion Rights in France’s Constitution
item.description: The bill, which developed in response to the U.S. Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade, may face opposition in France’s Senate and would have to be approved in a referendum.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Sarah Meyssonnier/Reuters
item.media:description: Members of the French National Assembly celebrated a vote to ensure abortion rights in the Constitution in Paris on Thursday.

item.title: Meet the World’s New Human Rights Crisis Manager. He Has a Lot to Do.
item.description: From Somalia to Ukraine to Xinjiang in China, Volker Türk will have no shortage of challenges as he steps into one of the United Nations’ most delicate roles.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Salvatore Di Nolfi
item.media:description: Volker Türk, the new United Nations high commissioner for human rights, at his office in Geneva in October.

item.title: John McFall Is the World’s First Disabled Astronaut
item.description: John McFall, who lost a leg in a motorcycle accident when he was a teenager, was recruited by the European Space Agency and could soon be headed for space.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Francois Mori/Associated Press
item.media:description: “I can bring inspiration,” John McFall, 41, said on Wednesday. “Inspiration that science is for everyone,” he added, and that, “potentially, space is for everyone.”

item.title: Anwar Ibrahim Is Prime Minister of Malaysia, After a Wait of Decades
item.description: Anwar Ibrahim, whose career has also included a stint as deputy prime minister and two jail terms, said he had the alliances to command a “convincing majority” in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Fazry Ismail/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim leaving a news conference in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday. His appointment was the culmination of a stunning comeback.

item.title: Pakistan Names a New Army Chief, Amid Political Drama Centered on the Military
item.description: The appointment of Lt. Gen. Syed Asim Munir comes after weeks of intense speculation and backstage negotiations over who would lead the nuclear-armed military.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Press Information Department, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released by Pakistan’s government showing the newly appointed army chief, Lt. Gen. Syed Asim Munir, right, meeting with President Arif Alvi, in Islamabad, on Thursday.

item.title: Thousands of Indonesian Volunteers Search for Survivors After Earthquake
item.description: Amid aftershocks and landslides from Monday’s deadly quake in West Java, bands of volunteer rescuers have put aside their daily lives to save others.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers looking for relatives in Cugenang village after a landslide caused by an earthquake in Cianjur, West Java, Indonesia.

item.title: 2 Bomb Attacks in Jerusalem Kill 1 and Wound at Least 18
item.description: The attacks prompted calls by far-right leaders for the swift formation of a new government that would be tougher on terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Menahem Kahana/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli security forces at the scene of an explosion at a bus stop in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Lebanese Shepherds Accused of Spying Along Disputed Border With Israel
item.description: Lebanese herders say that Israel crosses an ill-defined frontier to abduct and interrogate them. Israel accuses the herders of espionage on behalf of Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Tamara Saade for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lebanese herders risk detention and interrogation by the Israeli military when they take their flocks to graze on disputed lands along the border between Lebanon and Israel.

item.title: How Iran’s Security Forces Use Ambulances to Suppress Protests
item.description: Witness accounts and video analysis reveal how the state is co-opting ambulances to infiltrate demonstrations and detain protesters.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Ishaan Jhaveri
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Parent Company of Yandex, Known as ‘Russia’s Google,’ Wants to Cut Ties With Country
item.description: The move would be a setback to President Vladimir V. Putin’s efforts to develop homegrown substitutes for Western technology.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oleg Matsnev
item.media:credit: Sefa Karacan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Yandex taxi driving through the Red Square in Moscow in 2020.

item.title: Surgeons in Ukraine Struggle to Operate When the Power Goes Out
item.description: The scene in a Kyiv hospital was a vivid illustration of the cascading toll Russia’s attacks are having on civilians far from the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Bernat Armangue/Associated Press
item.media:description: Doctors operating on a 13-year-old patient at a hospital in Kherson, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Indonesia Earthquake Takes a Heavy Toll on Children
item.description: Children accounted for a third of the at least 272 dead when an earthquake hit Indonesia this week. Experts say the disaster highlights poor building standards in rural areas.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat, Mike Ives, Seth Mydans and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:description: Neng Didah, 34, holding a photo of her daughter, Dewi Hani, on Thursday. Hani died when her school collapsed in an earthquake in West Java on Monday.

item.title: Happy Thanksgiving
item.description: Everything is going to turn out all right today.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sifton
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dry-brined turkey.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Heavy Russian strikes on infrastructure targets in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke from a Russian artillery bombardment rising on Wednesday from the port of the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson, which has come under daily shelling this week from Russian positions located across the Dnipro River.

item.title: Russian Missile Barrage Cuts Power and Water Across Ukraine
item.description: Outages struck Kyiv and the surrounding region, as well as Lviv, Dnipro, Odesa and Kharkiv. Half of Moldova, whose grid is tied to Ukraine’s, also lost power.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke from a Russian artillery bombardment rising on Wednesday from the port of the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson, which has come under daily shelling this week from Russian positions located across the Dnipro River.

item.title: Judge Slaps Down Bolsonaro’s Late Bid to Overturn Brazil’s Election
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro’s campaign argued many votes should be nullified because of a software bug. But experts said the bug did not affect the vote, and Brazil’s elections chief dismissed the complaint.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, center at top, waited two days to publicly address his loss. When he did, he refused to concede. Now, he’s challenging the results.

item.title: Pope Compares Russia’s War in Ukraine to Stalin-Era Famine That Killed Millions
item.description: The comparison to Stalin’s decision to let millions in Ukraine starve represents one of the pope’s strongest condemnations yet of the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Yara Nardi/Reuters
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Bombs Kill a Teenager in Jerusalem
item.description: Plus: Blackouts in Ukraine, Japan’s soccer triumph and an A.I. Thanksgiving menu.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Illean/Associated Press
item.media:description: Aryeh Schupak, a 15-year-old yeshiva student, was killed in the bombings.

item.title: US Bolsters Ukrainian Military With $400 Million in Aid
item.description: A new shipment of $400 million in matériel underscores Ukraine’s battlefield priorities: shooting down waves of Russian missiles while continuing to push back Moscow’s ground forces.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Hannibal Hanschke/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A HIMARS unit fired by the Ukrainian military in the Kherson region of Ukraine in early November. The newest U.S. military aid package to Ukraine includes ammunition for the system.

item.title: Thieves Steal Ancient Gold Coins From German Museum
item.description: The theft played out like the plot of a movie. The artifacts could be worth $1.7 million if sold to dealers — or $260,000 if melted down.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Frank Maechler/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Celtic coins and other artifacts on display at the museum in 2006.

item.title: UK Acknowledges Signs of Race Disparity Over Joint Enterprise Cases
item.description: The government recognition that “joint enterprise” prosecutions may “affect some groups disproportionately,” an apparent first, followed a Times investigation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest organized by Joint Enterprise Not Guilty by Association, a group set up to fight joint-enterprise convictions, outside Parliament in London in May.

item.title: The European Parliament Backs Designating Russia as a State Sponsor of Terrorism
item.description: The European Union’s only directly elected institution called on the bloc to “further isolate Russia internationally.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians lined up for humanitarian aid in Kherson, Ukraine, last week. Millions have been displaced because of the war, while thousands are believed to have been killed.

item.title: BBC Could Have Been More Critical of Russia During 2018 World Cup, Its Commentator Says
item.description: Gary Lineker, a former England player and prominent TV presenter, said the broadcaster made a “mistake” that it would learn from in Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: May James/Reuters
item.media:description: Gary Lineker, a former soccer player for England, recently discussed the BBC’s coverage of Russia during the 2018 World Cup.

item.title: Squatters Can Stay at a Russian Tech Entrepreneur’s Property in Amsterdam, a Dutch Court Rules
item.description: The owner is Arkady Volozh, the founder of the Russian tech colossus Yandex, who stepped aside after coming under E.U. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: Arkady Volozh, a prominent Russian tech entrepreneur, at an investment forum in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: Russian Missile Strikes Maternity Ward, Killing Newborn, Ukraine Says
item.description: “Grief fills our hearts,” a regional official said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Rescuers at the site of a maternity ward of a hospital destroyed by a Russian missile attack, in Vilniansk, Zaporizhzhia region, on Wednesday.

item.title: UK Supreme Court Bars Scotland From Unilateral Independence Referendum
item.description: In a setback to Scottish nationalists, the judges ruled that a second referendum on breaking away from London needed the consent of the British Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Campaigners for Scottish independence outside the British Supreme Court in London on Wednesday. A previous vote on breaking away fell short in 2014.

item.title: Marijuana Majority
item.description: Americans support marijuana legalization, but many of their political leaders do not.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marijuana growing under specialized lighting at Harmony Dispensary in Secaucus, N.J. in 2018.

item.title: Earth Now Has 8 Billion Humans. This Man Wishes There Were None.
item.description: For the sake of the planet, Les Knight, the founder of the Voluntary Human Extinction movement, has spent decades pushing one message: “May we live long and die out.”
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times

item.title: Read Your Way Through Tangier
item.description: Tangier’s many facets have long inspired writers. Here, the Moroccan-born novelist Laila Lalami introduces readers to the books and writers that, to her, best capture the city.
item.dc:creator: Laila Lalami
item.media:credit: Raphaelle Macaron

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A closer look at the state of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier near Kherson, this month.

item.title: Missiles for Poland May Disrupt NATO’s Stance on Ukraine War
item.description: NATO is determined to help Ukraine battle Russia, but wants no direct part of the war. A new promise of air defense weapons for Poland may make that more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Tytus Zmijewski/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An American Patriot surface-to-air missile system at a military training center in Torun, Poland, in October.

item.title: Ukraine Raids Holy Site Amid Suspicion of Orthodox Church Tied to Moscow
item.description: The security services said they searched for spies and weapons at the Monastery of the Caves in Kyiv. Dozens of priests have been arrested since the war began on charges of aiding Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Monastery of the Caves in Kyiv after the Security Service of Ukraine raided the Orthodox Christian monastery and religious complex on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Indonesia’s Death Toll Climbs
item.description: Plus Saudi Arabia defeats Argentina, Australia loses to France and lockdowns spread across China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Yulius Satria Wijaya/Antara Foto, via Reuters
item.media:description: Rescuers carried a body bag through the rubble during a rescue operation in Cianjur, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Hebe de Bonafini, 93, Who Rallied Mothers of ‘the Disappeared,’ Dies
item.description: She was a key force behind a 1970s human rights movement demanding justice from Argentina’s brutal military dictatorship. Her extreme leftist views later made her a polarizing figure.
item.dc:creator: Ana Lankes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo
item.media:credit: Eduardo Di Baia/Associated Press
item.media:description: Hebe de Bonafini, center, in 1979. She and other mothers of people who had disappeared under Argentina’s brutal military dictatorship held a vigil every Thursday at Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires.

item.title: UK Starts to Look at Brexit With ‘Bregret’
item.description: Stung by inflation and bracing for tax increases, the country is in the midst of its gravest slump in a generation, leading many to wonder how much the split with the European Union is to blame.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Oli Scarff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chester, northwestern England, this month. Among the Group of 7 advanced countries, Britain is the only one with an economy that is smaller now than it was before the pandemic started.

item.title: Drone Attack Strikes Sevastopol in Crimea, Kremlin-backed Official Says
item.description: After a drone attack in October, Russia temporarily suspended its cooperation with a deal that allowed Ukrainian grain safe passage through the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
item.media:description: The Black Sea seen from Cape Fiolent, outside the Crimean port city of Sevastopol, in 2018.

item.title: Photos from China’s Latest Covid-19 Lockdowns
item.description: Empty streets, shuttered shops, long lines at coronavirus testing sites and other scenes from China as it tries to combat rapidly spreading outbreaks in cities across the country.
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers fumigating manholes in Shenzhen, China, this month.

item.title: Almost Safe, She Returned to Munich and Lost a Bronzino and Her Life
item.description: A portrait by Bronzino that Ilse Hesselberger once owned is coming up for sale, a reminder of the brutality, and twists of fate, that Jews confronted in the Nazi era.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan

item.title: The War With Russia Has Further Divided Orthodox Churches in Ukraine
item.description: The leaders of the central branch of the Orthodox church in Ukraine made a formal break with the hierarchy in Moscow in April.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kyiv Pechersk Lavra monastery after Ukraine’s security service conducted a raid on Tuesday.

item.title: To the Moon
item.description: NASA is on a return mission.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: NASA
item.media:description: A portion of the far side of the moon looms large just beyond the Orion spacecraft.

item.title: South Africa’s Cyril Ramaphosa Wins a Crucial A.N.C. Battle
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa emerged well-placed to win a second term as the head of the country’s governing party, although there is much haggling and horse-trading to come.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa is fighting a leadership challenge that represents a crossroads for the governing African National Congress.

item.title: Kamala Harris Promises Support and Denounces China During Philippines Visit
item.description: The vice president accused China of “intimidation and coercion” in disputed waters, as the Biden administration seeks partners to counter Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: During a trip to Palawan, the province closest to the disputed Spratly Islands, Vice President Kamala Harris said the United States stood with the Philippines “in the face of intimidation and coercion,” a remark aimed at China.

item.title: China’s Grandparents Are Done Babysitting and Ready to Go Viral
item.description: Rapping grannies, crooning 70-year-olds and gamers in their 80s are challenging traditional Chinese views about aging and what it means to have a long and happy life.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: The four members of Glamma Beijing shooting a video in the Chinese capital.

item.title: The Cool, Wild and Very Remote Andaman Islands
item.description: This archipelago in the Indian Ocean offers pristine nature, Indian culture, a glimpse of fascinating communities and some of the most spectacular beaches in the world.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chidiya Tapu beach outside Port Blair, the capital of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, is one of the island group’s many beautiful beaches.

item.title: Indonesia Rescue Efforts Underway After Earthquake Kills At Least 268
item.description: As workers try to find survivors, rescue efforts have been hampered by power outages and blocked roads in a disaster that has killed at least 268 people and injured more than a thousand.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/Reuters
item.media:description: Rescue workers lifting a body in Cianjur, West Java province, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: China Factory Fire Kills 38
item.description: Officials say an investigation is underway into what caused the tragedy at the two-story facility operated by a wholesaler of industrial equipment, clothing and chemical products.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: CCTV, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The factory in Anyang, China, on Monday, in this image taken from video footage run by the state broadcaster, CCTV.

item.title: Beijing Is Tackling Air Pollution. Why Can’t New Delhi?
item.description: The return of smog season in India’s capital has again left residents asking why nothing has changed. The answer may be largely political.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj, Matt Stevens, John Yoon and Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Money Sharma/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The India Gate in New Delhi this month. Recent high levels of pollution in Delhi have prompted officials to halt truck traffic, close schools and ask people to work from home.

item.title: Outbreaks Test China’s Efforts to Limit the Cost of ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: China wants to fine-tune its stringent pandemic restrictions to reduce the disruption to daily life caused by lockdowns. But officials are still taking few chances.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Security guards dressed in protective equipment at an office building in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A devastating earthquake has killed more than 150 people in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Rangga Firmansyah/Associated Press

item.title: Ukraine Defies Odds in War With Russia, But Still Has Far to Go
item.description: Ukraine is on the offensive along most of the 600-mile front line, and the Russians are in a defensive crouch. But about one-fifth of Ukrainian territory is still occupied by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Kherson, this month.

item.title: Ukraine Remembers Maidan Protests, a Milestone Toward Putin’s War
item.description: In hindsight, protests that began nine years ago and toppled a Ukrainian president were a pivot point in efforts by Vladimir V. Putin to exert Russian control over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antigovernment protests in Ukraine led to the downfall of President Viktor Yanukovych in February 2014.

item.title: Indonesia Earthquake Photos Show Wide Damage
item.description: The quake that toppled hundreds of buildings on the island of Java also blocked roads needed to get medical help to victims.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indonesian search and rescue teams looking in the village of Cugenang, West Java, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Women and Nonbinary People, Monkeypox Cases May Have Been Missed
item.description: Despite monkeypox fading from public attention, scientists are still learning how it spreads — including without sexual contact or any symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Kholood Eid for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mobile monkeypox vaccine unit in Brooklyn this month.

item.title: Bao Tong, 90, Dies; Top Chinese Official Imprisoned After Tiananmen
item.description: He helped design China’s political reforms in the 1980s and tried to avert the bloodshed that ended the democracy protests. After prison, he became a critic of the party.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Goh Chai Hin/AFP, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Bao in 2011. Before the crackdown in Tiananmen, he was charged with leaking that martial law was coming, an allegation he vehemently denied. He was sentenced to seven years in prison.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Indonesia’s Deadly Earthquake
item.description: Plus Iranian players protest at the World Cup and “Neighbours” will start filming again.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Rangga Firmansyah/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescuers searched for survivors in a destroyed house in Cianjur, Indonesia, after the area was hit by 5.6-magnitude earthquake on Monday.
